PAWNBROKERS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

10.10 a.m.

    The Assistant Minister, Chief Secretary's Ministry (Mr M. P. D. Nair): Sir, I rise to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    For a good number of years the practice of issuing licences to pawnbrokers in Singapore has been based on a three-year tender system. Normally the highest bidder is successful and pays a monthly rental equal to his 'bid' which depends on the locality of the business and the number of competitors for the licence. The fees range from $6,000 to $56,000 a year. In 1955, realising that the system was out of date and needy of change, Government appointed a Committee to review the system and to make recommendations for a new one and to draft any necessary legislation. The Committee's findings and the Government's White Paper on it which has accepted the main recommendations, were published and presented as Sessional Paper No. Cmd. 62 of 1956.

    Sir, since the publication of this White Paper, several letters have been received in my Ministry as well as in the Chief Minister's Office indicating a general acceptance of the recommendations of the White Paper. The Bill is the culmination of the investigations instituted, and it sets out to amend the Pawnbrokers Ordinance (Chapter 195)

Column: 1574

so as to incorporate such of the recommendations of the Committee which have been accepted by Government.

    The main object of the Bill, Sir, is to establish a Pawnbrokers Licensing Board responsible generally for the regulation of the pawnbroking business and particularly for the consideration annually of applications for licences, for the issue, refusal and cancellation of licences, and for the receipt of fees and monthly returns from licensees. The constitution of the Board, the definition of the scope of its duties, the conditions subject to which licences may be granted, recourse to the Minister for persons aggrieved by the Board's decisions, and the duties of the pawnbrokers in respect of pledges remaining in their custody after the determination of their licences, are all matters provided for in clause 3 of the Bill.

    The proviso to section 9 (1) (c), Sir, proposed by clause 3 of the Bill, safeguards the banking business which is commonly conducted by pawnbrokers in Singapore as a sideline.

    Clause 4 of the Bill provides that pawnbrokers may be required to make monthly returns to the Board in accordance with rules made under section 45 of the Ordinance. Such returns would be of value in determining, for instance, the extent of the community's dependence on the services of the pawnbrokers.

    Clause 5 of the Bill amends section 24 of the Ordinance so as to simplify the calculation of a pawnbroker's liability in respect of pledges destroyed or damaged by, or in consequence of, fire.

    Clause 6 of the Bill amplifies the provisions of section 45 of the Ordinance, defining the purposes for which rules may be made under this Ordinance.

    Clause 6 (e) of the Bill provides for rules for the procedure to be followed by applicants and the procedure and proceedings of the Board.

    Clause 7 of the Bill introduces an amended schedule of profits allowed to pawnbrokers. The new schedule provides for a maximum rate of interest of two per cent per month.

    Clause 8 of the Bill is designed to make amendments passim to provisions

Column: 1575

in the Ordinance which require to be brought up to date in reference to the amount of loans and to the maximum fines that may be imposed for offences under the Ordinance, and other amendments resulting in the constitution of the proposed Pawnbrokers Licensing Board which replaces the existing Licensing Authority.

    While clause 3 of the Bill provides the basis for the procedure and proceedings of the Board and that of applicants and applications, regulations are being framed to make more specific provisions in these respects, especially in regard to reference to departments, advertising of applications, notice of objections from the public and departments, fees for licences, and display of licences.

    Clause 8 (1) of the Bill provides for the fee to be prescribed by the Governor in Council and this will be done under the regulations which are being made. Neither the Committee's Report nor the White Paper has provided for any basis of classification or the scale of fees. However, it has been the view that the fees collected should not be looked upon as a revenue measure but as a means of covering the cost of the administrative system. It is proposed, Sir, to have classifications and fees as shown below.

CLERKS EMPLOYMENT BILL
(Report from Select Committee)


10.31 a.m.

    The Minister for Labour and Welfare (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move the motion standing in my name, namely,

    That the Report from the Select Committee on the Clerks Employment Bill, as

Column: 1581

contained in Sessional Paper L.A. 2 of 1957, be adopted, subject to the recommittal of the Bill in respect of clause 27, clause 28, clause 29 and clause 46 to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    Sir, the Clerks Employment Bill was committed to a Select Committee and from Sessional Paper L.A. 2 of 1957, it will be seen that the Select Committee held five meetings. The minutes of the proceedings of these meetings can be found in Appendix III. The Bill reproduced in Appendix II contains all the amendments to the Bill recommended by the Select Committee. Most of the amendments made are minor ones for the purpose of improving the drafting of the Bill to clarify still further its provisions. The representations made by unions and employers have been duly considered but they are not considered to be of such substance as to make necessary amendments to the Bill.

    It must not be overlooked, Sir, that the Bill is an improvement on the previous Bill introduced by the Government during the last session and that account has already been taken of the representations then made. Moreover, the Bill has been considered by the Labour Advisory Board on which workers and employers are adequately represented.

    Sir, with reference to the telegram from the Singapore Business Houses Employees' Union, the points raised therein have been given due and careful consideration and it was felt that there should be a distinction between clerical workers in offices and those whose work bears a direct relation to the workmen in the same employment who are covered by the Labour Code. There are tally clerks, supervisors, store clerks, etc.

    The Report of the Select Committee has been in the hands of hon. Members for some time and I do not therefore propose to deal with it at great length. I am confident that this Assembly will support my motion and so ensure that the conditions of employment of clerks are set to a standard of which Singapore can be proud and that our clerical workers can enjoy this new charter on Labour Day.

    The proposal, Sir, to recommit the Bill in respect of the clauses named is

10.35 a.m.

    Mr Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, the clerical workers of Singapore are undoubtedly the most docile, the most humble, the most timid group of people in the island and a group with less money to spare than most. This group, the clerical workers of Singapore, unlike the Singapore Federation of Employers, did not have a lawyer to present their views to the Select Committee at the last time or this time. We have promised them for a long time not a maximum standard of living Bill but a law to protect them against unreasonable exploitation, a law to give them statutory minimum conditions of service. There is much that is very good in this Bill. There are nevertheless provisions of a character which by some extraordinary oversight have slipped in which make it not a clerks Bill but an employers Bill and not even an ordinary employers Bill, because there are many very decent employers, but the Singapore Federation of Employers Bill, that Federation which through the pages of these reports and last year's Select Committee's reports comes through as a mean and crafty scrooge.

    Sir, I have had an illuminating talk this morning with the Attorney-General and I am glad to note that at least in respect of clauses 6 and 7 there was never the intention to have the effect which they do have but I shall take, clause by clause, the clauses to which I take objection and then I shall ask this House to give me an opportunity to put the arguments before you in Committee. I do not ask you to accept at this stage what I am suggesting to be true but I do ask you to permit me to amend this motion before you so that we can recommit ten other clauses to a Committee of the whole House to consider them quietly.

Column: 1583



    Sir, the first clause which I shall ask for recommittal is clause 2. Clause 2 creates three classes of clerks. God created only two classes of human beings, men and women. We are asked to create by law: one, clerks earning more than $500 a month and clerks earning less; two, clerks working in offices; three, industrial clerks. They are all different. Clerks earning more than $500 a month have no protection whatsoever. Industrial clerks as compared to clerks have to work 44 hours instead of 39 hours a week, get only seven days holidays instead of 14 days for annual leave and 11 days instead of 13 days for public holidays. The Minister for Labour and Welfare is a Socialist, as we all are in this House, barring Mr Sutherland - no offence meant, Sir. He frankly said, "I represent capital, so what! And I am proud of it." Fair enough! Everybody else in this House says that he is a Socialist. Well, Sir, let us then look at it as Socialists, as honest people who seek to assist these really helpless people - this group known as the clerical workers.

    Sir, the Singapore Clerical and Administrative Workers' Union at page 4 of this Report protested against limiting clerks to those under $500 a month. It says:

    "... that all persons clerically employed should come within the meaning of and benefit by the Ordinance otherwise clerks drawing salaries exceeding $500 would not be able to claim the privileges contained in the Ordinance."

Now, Sir, again the Confederation of Singapore Chinese Engineering Tradesmen Union at column 37 of Annexe I protested against this and in its letter of 12th November, 1956, it says:

    "Our interpretation of the contents of United Engineers' letter is that they will adhere strictly to the provisions of the Clerks Employment Ordinance, when passed, and, in its present form, apart from giving no protection whatsoever to clerical workers drawing more than $500 per month, it provides less benefits than currently enjoyed by U.E. workers who would be classified as "Industrial Clerks" under the Ordinance, in that they would be allowed one week annual leave against two weeks now enjoyed by them, and they would work 44 hours weekly, instead of 40 hours at present."

Sir, the Attorney-General in Select Committee seemed to suggest that the

Column: 1584

$500 limit was necessary for ease of administration and I think you will find that at columns 2, 3 and 4 of the Minutes of Evidence.

    Sir, I for myself would like to ask the House to permit the recommittal of this clause for closer scrutiny. I say that there is really no valid reason whatsoever for putting this arbitrary limit of $500 except that the Singapore Employers Federation, seeking the maximum possible control in the minimum possible conditions of service for these workers, has asked that there be a limit and it be $400. Any decent human being who has read the representations of the Singapore Employers Federation should take the attitude that everything they say is suspect. It is evil: those documents that they have put in and the control that they seek to have over these entirely helpless human beings whom they employ as fodder for their obscene profits.

    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland (Nominated): Come, come!

    Mr Marshall: Come, come! I have asked repeatedly in this House, Mr Speaker, Sir, for a declaration as to the profits earned by these companies and it has never been available.
